instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3330: What is 820-3330? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPVOUT_S0_LCDBKLT: What is PPVOUT_S0_LCDBKLT? PPVOUT_S0_LCDBKLT is a power rail that powers the LED light in the screen of the device that allows you to see what is on the screen. When this is low or missing, the screen will be dim..
definitions.BKL_PWM: What is BKL_PWM? BKL_PWM sets the brightness of the screen. The system will send a PWM signal to BKL_PWM pin to set brightness. If this is low, backlight voltage will boost higher than PPBUS_G3H input, but not enough to make the screen light properly..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B no backlight but <SIGNAL>PP3V3_SW_LCD</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0_DDC_LCD</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PPVOUT_S0_LCDBKLT</SIGNAL> ok [FIXED]
threads.message:
I'm working on a <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B; MacBook Pro does boot, there is a chime, and there is image, but no backlight.

I measured voltages on J9000.

I do have 3.308V on pins 2&3
I do have 40V on pins 38, always, but 0V on pin 39 (sometimes 30V) and 0V on pin 40. Probably a measurement issue, because 9 times out of 10 I get 0V, and 1 out of 10 a nice 40V on each pin
I do have 3.342V on pin 4, 6 and 7

I checked <RESISTOR>R9010</RESISTOR> and <RESISTOR>R9011</RESISTOR>, they both are at 4.5kOhms
These two resistances read 100kOhms on another similar MacBook (which does not turn on)

Can it be an issue there ?

I tested with another screen : no backlight, but picture.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B no backlight but <SIGNAL>PP3V3_SW_LCD</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0_DDC_LCD</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PPVOUT_S0_LCDBKLT</SIGNAL> ok [FIXED]
threads.message:
40V is a correct voltage for this 15" machine.
Try 2-3 times PRAM and SMC reset.

Check <SIGNAL>BKL_PWM</SIGNAL> voltage.

Pins 38-40 are connected directly on the board; not sure how can you get different voltage readings.
Just in case, change J9000.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B no backlight but <SIGNAL>PP3V3_SW_LCD</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0_DDC_LCD</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PPVOUT_S0_LCDBKLT</SIGNAL> ok [FIXED]
threads.message:
PRAM and SMC reset already tried; 
<SIGNAL>BKL_PWM</SIGNAL> is at 2.500V, measured on <CAPACITOR>C9704</CAPACITOR>
I agree about pins 38-40, i should read the same value on each but most of the time (90%) I don't.

I will replace this J9000 tomorrow, and update this post after. Wanted to be sure I didn't miss anything obvious

Thanks

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B no backlight but <SIGNAL>PP3V3_SW_LCD</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0_DDC_LCD</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PPVOUT_S0_LCDBKLT</SIGNAL> ok [FIXED]
threads.message: J9000 was the culprit. Connector replaced.
